JOE.raw_line: Time travel has not yet been invented. But twenty five years from now it will be. Once the technology exists, it will be relatively cheap and available to the public at large. And so. It will be instantly outlawed, used only in secret by the largest criminal organizations. And then only for a very specific purpose. Joe drives up and parks his truck, removes the wrapped corpse from the flatbed.It's nearly impossible to dispose of a body in the future. I'm told. Tagging techniques, whatnot. So when these future criminal organizations in the future need someone gone, they use specialized assassins in our present, called loopers.And so. Thirty years from now. My employers in the future nab the target, they zap him back to me, their looper. And I do the necessaries. So the target has vanished from the future, and I've just disposed of a body that technically does not exist. Clean. The body slides down a long chute. Vanishes in a little flare of angry red fire.Bon jour, Beatrix.Slow. How's the coffee?Two, Jedd.Yup. Dale hands four gold bars through the slot as Joe retrieves his gun and exits.Bon jour, mademoiselle. Bang!Yeah Seth? Yeah. Ok.Seth.That's new. Seth kicks the bike.Slat Bikes are all junk. Stick with rubber on the road.They get respect cause they run the town. How much did that thing set you back? How much? Seth holds a quarter idly in his palm.Congratulations. You're pulling up with me instead. Joe notices the floating quarter.And don't, if we're going in, don't do that.It's tacky, don't do it. Seth catches the quarter, sullen.When the TK mutation started appearing in the general populace it was on every magazine - âNext Step in Evolution, what's next.â Everyone got tested. But turns out this was it, and now it's just a bunch of assholes thinking they're blowing your mind by floating quarters.Big heads. Small potatoes. Drives past, revving the engine.We'll stick backstage, just meeting up. In and out.Hardly. Right Seth?So I've read. He ducks out.What?For what?No shit? The door at the bottom of the stairs opens, and ZACH, another looper, steps out. An OLDER MAN'S HAND pats his shoulder then retracts into the door. The loopers watch him in awe.There's a reason we're called loopers.Time travel in the future is so illegal, that when we sign up for this job we agree to a very specific proviso.If our employers in the future get busted up by the law, their first priority is going to be erasing any trace of their relationship with us ever existing. A flash of light, and a HOG TIED MAN with a sack over his head kneels in front of Zach. Zach fires, and the man's chest explodes.So. If they're busted, and if we're still alive 30 years from now, they'll find our older self and zap him back to us, like any other job. Zach rips open the back of the corpse's jacket, revealing several dozen gold bars taped to his back.This is called closing your loop. Zach freezes. Looks at the shape of the corpse's face through the sack.And you get paid out a mythic amount of money, and you get a handshake and get released from your contract. Enjoy the next 30 years.This job doesn't tend to attract the most forward thinking people.Sell that goddamn slat bike back. That's a lot of stupid money.Alright. Seth stumbles toward his door, checks his pants.Hey Seth. Seth slumps against the car.Alright, Zach. What's his payout, 30? 40? If that? That's not going to last you 30 years. And it won't get you overseas.So in five, ten years you're back to riding the rails, or worse you're like Kid Blue, working as a gat man, wagging your dick at loopers and roughing up shop clerks for payoff money.Save a little something. Alright? Cause that'll be yours, and then you've got yours and that's all that matters, your life is your own.Ravi de te voir, Beatrix.Two, Jedd. Jedd opens a slot and takes two gold bars from Joe, then hands him out a small stack of cash. Marks in a notebook Joe's name, the date and the number â2'. All the other transactions have the number â4'.Fourth. On the stage, flinging her legs with a line of can-can dancers, is Suzie. The girl Joe watched in the bordello. As her dance ends Joe stands and goes backstage.You working a shift tonight?Oh.Jesus, Seth.No, they're not here. Who?Seth, sit down here. CRASH! Seth knocks something over in the dark. Joe opens the fridge, pale light. Seth sits at the kitchen table.Tell me now.Seth, what did you do?I knew then what he did so I don't know why I asked.What did you do? Seth lifts his eyes to Joe.This is called letting your loop run. It's not a good thing.You fucking idiot coming here. Seth, sucker punched.You can't be here, I'll give you a little money but you gottaYou hop a freight train, you beat it the hell out POUND POUND POUND. On the door this time. Seth makes a sound like he's going to die, Joe closes the fridge, hissesShut up. Don't move. Goes to the door. Two GAT MEN and Kid Blue stand outside.I can't do anything for you Seth. Seth crumples to his knees, grasping Joe's hand.Hold on! Watching Seth, Joe's face breaks in a moment of decision. He flips the lights on, and briskly pulls back his oriental rug. A FLOOR SAFE with a touch pad. He enters a code, opens it. Wide and deeper than you'd expect, lined with gold bars. Big enough for a man. Seth scrambles in. Joe takes one last look at Seth's frightened, grateful face, framed by the gold bars, then closes the safe and smooths the oriental rug. POUND POUND POUND- Joe opens the door. Kid Blue storms in, his gun drawn, sweeping through the apartment with over-eager purpose. One gat man stays outside, the other casually sits at Joe's kitchen table. Kid Blue gets in Joe's face.You think it's easy looking this good?There's coffee in the tin.Alright, cut it out Kid. You're gonna blow your foot off again. The Kid almost snaps back, but then grins.C'mon.Dunno I agree with that.This man is from the future. He was sent back here by the mob, a one way ticket, to run the Loopers. That's low effort even for Abe, so to pass the time he recruited some real muscle, the Gat Men. Now he runs the city. Any other city, that'd be impressive. Abe settles in his chair. Regards Joe.Ties.Okay. A beat of silence.Well it was nice chatting with you Abe.Seth?My friend Seth? I'm confused.Watch shop.You know I'm grateful, Abe. Genuine. But Abe shakes his hands, not where he's going.Okay.Will you kill him?Floor safe, beneath the rug. 6742. One of the gat men quietly exits.I can't remember my mother's face. I remember her touching my hair. Like this. He takes Suzie's hand strokes it over his hair. She smiles briefly, tired, then takes her hand away and puts drops in his eyes.Do you want to go overseas?Soon, maybe.Is that how it aughta be?Oh god. Gold bars scattered in the dirt. But no Old Joe. And no truck. Joe staggers to his feet, shaky. Head thick. But realizing.Late to my own funeral.Kid listen Kid. I'm sorry. Tell Abe I'm going to fix this. Tell him keep my bars safe cause I swear to god I'm going to fix this, I'm going to find my loop and I'm gonna kill him. Tell Abe- CRACK CRACK! The wood paneled floor above the safe door splinters upwards with gunshots, and a chunk of Joe's right ear explodes. More blood than you'd think spills down his neck, Joe falls back. Three more shots - CRACK CRACK CRACK! And now footsteps running down the hall. Joe on his feet, slipping in his own blood, sprints across the apartment. The TALL GAT MAN appears in the doorway, shooting blindly at Joe, chunks of wall and plaster exploding as Joe doesn't stop but JUMPS OUT THE WINDOW.Where would I go if I were me.I ordered something....ok.Yeah. Didn't know if you'dI'm not cutting myself again to-It's an interesting question, I've just lost a lot of blood today.Good.I don't care what you're here for, whatever you think you're going to get from me. More time or whatever you want. I can't let you walk away from this diner alive. Because the next 30 years of myI've got a life ahead of me that's mine and I'm not giving it up for you or anybodyYour face looks backwards.I wasn't trying to. Do you know what's going to happen? Have you already done all this, right now, as me?When I hurt myself now, it changes your body. Do my actions change your memories?What's the pepper?So you canSo when we're apart you can remember what I do. After I do it.Who? Old Joe takes a worn double of Joe's POCKET WATCH from his pocket, clicks it open. We don't see inside it, but he stares at it intently.This is a woman, what? I'm going to fall in love with?She's. How is she, you said save my life.My life is my own, I don't need itSeth said, that night. A new boss in the future, he said.That would take an army.How did he do it?None of this concerns me. We're done we're gonna walk outside now.It happened to you, it doesn't have to happen to me. You got her picture in there? Show it to me. Show me her picture. And when I see her for the first time I'll walk away, and she won't be with me.I guarantee the instant I look at her picture that fog in your brain will swallow up the memories of her and she'll be gone.She'll be safe. And then we can all do what we have to do. A beat. Old Joe holding the pocket watch, gazing at it. Then he snaps it closed in his fist, drawing it back.It's been awhile since we've gotten a warm-up. Old Joe realizes, looks around. The diner is eerily quiet. Beatrix and the staff have all quietly left. Fled. Old Joe swings out of the booth, still holding Joe by the hair, dragging him like a doll. Joe's blunderbuss clatters to the ground. Old Joe drags him to the window. They look out. Nothing in the parking lot. Too quiet.I've got him! He's here! A GAT MAN barrels in, his gat blazing. Joe scrambles but Old Joe gets the gat. With an expert shot Old Joe puts the Gat Man down, but there are two more behind him. Pinned behind a booth, Old Joe returns fire, glass breaking and chaos. Joe grabs at the papers, Old Joe grabs them first and yanks. Leaving Joe with a torn-off top sheet. Joe scrambles away, down the length of the diner behind the booths, back to their table, as the Gat Men and Old Joe have their fire fight. Joe's blunderbuss on the ground beneath the table. He scoops it up. Turns, and fires at Old Joe.Around back!No fuck no fucking piece of shit CLICK CLICK. The Kid and the Gats closing in, and just the moment that Kid Blue lays his hands on the back of the bike the engine turns over with a ROAR. The back of the bike kicks up, heat and air blasts from the open slats beneath, blowing Kid Blue back on his ass. The bike HOVERS a few feet off the ground. Joe roars off into the corn. The Kid is on his feet running back to the Gat Men.C'mon. C'mere. C'mon. C'mon. C'mon.A day.Thirsty. I can't feel my legsThirsty. Thirsty. Soft footsteps approach. Small bare feet padding towards him through the front door. A young boy steps out onto the porch, 6 years old, named CID. Cid looks Joe over. His eyes linger on Joe's gun. Then he kneels, his small hands feeling Joe's sweaty face. Pushes a straw to Joe's lips. Joe's hands clasp around a plastic cup with a cartoon tiger, and he drinks.I just finished cleaning - alright. Tosses it into the dirt. Sara lowers the shotgun slightly.I'm at thirty percent.I can't do that.I need to stay here for a little while longer.Well I'm sorry.No. Sara raises the shotgun.No. You couldn't scare a retarded hobo with that thing. Literally.And that's, that's telling. You're holding a gun. I say I'm not afraid, so you describe the gun to me. But it's not the gun I'm not afraid of.Look I'm not a threat to you or your boy. I need to be on your property but I'd prefer to not have any contact with you at all, I'll stay in the fields. There's just one thing you need to do for me, and you won't have to deal with me again. He takes the map from his pocket, unfolds it. Tosses it over to her.Just, verify for me that's your house on the map. So I know I'm in the right place.A map.Doesn't matter. Ok. I'll be out of the barn in an hour, if you can spare it I'll take the water jug with me. Does that well have water? I'll fill it from there. Sara turns the map over. Sees the NUMBER that Old Joe wrote on the back. 07153902935. And everything changes.Does that mean something to you? For the first time in their conversation, Joe looks in her eyes. Sara stares daggers, searching. Very different than she was ten seconds ago. Joe scoots backTime travel hasn't been invented yet. But in thirty years it will be.I can't go back to the city and find him cause Abe, the boss, all his men are going to search the streets 24/7 till they turn up me or... him. All I have is this map. And that he's coming here. Sara stands. Paces away. Deep in thought.Yeah. Did you know about Loopers, what we doI think... he thinks, the instant the rainmaker dies, he'll never have been sent back, so he'll just vanish, and be back with his wife.Yeah. Someone. You know what these numbers mean.Think about what doing this would fix. What he thinks it would fix. Sara caught that, and she did not like it.He'll kill the other kids on that map and then come here last. Put off facing me.I've lost my life. I kill this man, I get it back. You can trust me.We're surrounded by the corn, that leaves us blind. He can get within fifty yards of the house without a hawk spotting him.What kind of equipment's in the barn?Nothing that shoots.Good by me. He hisses as she applies antiseptic to a gash in his arm.If I'm out here and you're in the house we're gonna need some way to communicate.Dinner bell. We need walkies, or buzzers.Got any ammo for that shotgun? That isn't a seasoning?What are we doing here?How do you do that?Smart.Let's say I kill people.Uh huh. Cid looks at him in the dark. Not scared at all. Then he goes back to fitting the backing on a toy. A long beat, Joe thinking. Broken by a PIERCING NOISE. They both jump - the toy truck Joe has idly played with is shrieking, sirens blaring. Joe fumbles with it, Cid reaches over and switches it off, they both freeze. And look up at the ceiling. Silence in the house. With a look of reproach beyond his years, Cid takes the truck from Joe and finishes up his work.How long have you and your mom been on the farm?I'm sorry.I'm sorry Takes the buzzers. Stands, fumbling. Retreating.You should talk to your mom about this.Can't you pull that out with a plow?I found a, in the barn I found some parts, and I made a, thing. Joe pushes one of Cid's BUZZERS into her hands, which we now see is a colorful plastic frog toy with a light bulb nose.If you see anything, just push that, and, Joe pushes the button on his buzzer, and Sara's lights up and vibrates. She regards the toy, then stares hard and cold at Joe.It's important.Last night. He woke me up. Don't tell him I told you though, he... Sara rolls her eyes, turns away. Starts chopping again. Joe doesn't leave.You said you were his mom.He told me you're not. This hits Sara hard. She resumes chopping to cover it.If he's not your son who is he?How'd she get killed? When Sara's eyes hit him they're daggers.Cid told me. You have to talk to him about it. Icy silence from Sara, and an odd stare.He asked about my gun. You think this is going to go away if you don't talk to him about it but it's just gonna growThank you granddad.No. I know him, that's what's funny. His name's Jesse. I like him. He'll go away when he doesn't find me, he won't hurt her. They watch in silence for awhile. In the distance, Jesse leaves the house alone and scopes the grounds before walking back towards the highway.My mom gave me up. I was younger than you. We were vagrants, and she was alone, for a long time I thought she was stupid for getting on the drug she was on, it was bad stuff, it probably ended up killing her.But now I see, she was so alone. And it was what she had. She sold me. To a panhandle gang. QUICKLY, SILENTLY WE SEE - FOUR YEAR OLD JOE dragged into darkness by rough men, screaming. Then we're back to the scene.But I got away. And I ran and I ended on a train, sitting in the dark in an empty freight, going to the city, and I saw myself over and over killing those men who bought me and who got my mom on what she was on. Finding them and tearing them apart. Saving my mom.A man in the city found me, put a gun in my hand, and gave me some things. I didn't have my mom anymore. I had my work, my money. My plans. For my life. That's what I'd kill for. Not something I don't have, and can't ever get back.I think we're clear. He opens the trap door, climbs out.What? Closes the door, kisses him. The adrenaline in his head doesn't know where to go.That's pretty good.He's protecting his future. Not mine. A beat.Jesse.I'm unarmed Jesse, you can let her go. Sara, Jesse here's the best shot with a gat I've ever seen, when he lets you go you sit on the couch and don't do anything stupid. Jesse lets Sara go and trains the gat on Joe.He's coming here Jess. My Looper, is gonna come here.I got eighty large in pure gold, I take my looper back in and get right with Abe, whatever he gives me back I'll split it with you.Ok. It's yours, all of itCid!How did your sister die? Sara holds his gaze. Then everything breaks inside her and she collapses in sobs. Heaving.That happened to her. Cid.What is it a TK mutation?Yeah I know he will. Imagine what he could do.He doesn't. Joe heads to the corn, Sara scampers after him but slips on the wet grass, and Joe hits the corn with a head start.Right now two things have happened. My looper knows Cid's the kid he's looking for, and my gang knows I'm here. So in fifteen minutes one or both is coming down that highway. You pack up the Gat Man's truck, whatever you can fit in ten minutes, and you drive North away from the city.One buzz means come and get me. Two or nothing, don't. He vanishes into the stalks, towards the highway.And you go kill the boy. That's how you fix it.My life? Your life. Becoming you.I haven't seen that yet. Joe fires again, close enough now to draw blood off Old Joe's chest and knock him back. Out of nowhere a SLAT BIKE careens around the van, which has until now blocked our line of sight down the highway. Kid Blue. The bike clips Joe's leg, sending him spinning violently to the dusty pavement. The bike shoots off down the highway, a cloud of dust in its wake. It takes a hundred yards for the Kid to pull it to a stop and spin it around. Joe is hurt bad. He grapples for his blunderbuss. Kid Blue guns the engine, gat in hand. Levels it, steady as a rock. Joe shoots at the Kid, but he's out of range, the gun fires scattershot. Kid Blue fires, a bullet hits dangerously close to Joe. Panicked, Joe begins firing at the pavement around him, round after fiery round. Kicking up dust. Lots of dust. Raising a cloud. KID BLUE'S POV - zooming towards Joe, now obscured in a cloud of dust and smoke. He fires his gat into the cloud, tries to slow the bike but can't in time. In the dust cloud Joe hears the bike roaring down upon him. He covers up and when he feels the bike roaring past blindly FIRES his buss. A moment later the bike emerges from the dust cloud. Without a driver. It skids, crashes. When the dust clears away Joe lies still, arms over his head.No!

OLD JOE.raw_line: And your jacket.Shit. Old Joe turns to go, but STOPS when his eye catches movement between parked cars. It's Joe. Young Joe, hid between the cars, looking up at the apartment building weighing his options.Stupid little shit. He lifts him in his arms.Please. Black. And water.Steak and eggs, rare and scrambled.We're not going to talk about time travel.Must hurt. His arm.I put it together. Clever.I'm not asking you to.You know there's another girl here on weekends.Well. Have fun explaining who âBeatrix' is for the next thirty years. Beatrix sets Old Joe's black coffee next to Joe's white.How's the French coming?(fast in French,No? Well you'll get there eventually. Obviously.You know what the voice of god sounds like? See now good you're confused now but you're listening. I hope the voice of god sounds like an old man speaking French. Old men speaking French sound like primeval trees in a strong wind, just irrefutable. Wise, strong, gentle, all these things in harmony, complimentary. At once. Old men speaking French. Young men speaking French sound, without exception, like weenies. Fact. You ever hear a Frenchman under 40 try to sound threatening? It's hilarious. English is a tight t- shirt, flatters the young. Rat a tat tat. French is a double breasted suit. Young man can put it on, but it always feels like he's putting something on. Some things, you just need the years. It's my favorite language.Well you know what you have to do then why don't you take your little gun out from between your knees and do it. One in the head, two in the heart. Boy. It's all âanybodyâ and âneverâ and then you show up here and think you can talk me into dying. Well bullshit we both know you're not going to kill me. Christ you ordered eggs. Old Joe downs two aspirin. Takes a breath.I know why you couldn't pull that trigger. When you're tasked to do the unthinkable, your mind, it'll do anything it can to stop you. Only way is you gotta know why you're doing it, in your bones, so you can say it out loud to someone without apologizing. Or you gotta cut yourself off, go numb. But that'll kill you, down the line.Yeah, that helps actually. That little twist of unfamiliar.No not - exactly - I don't want to talk about time travel shit, because we'll start talking about it and then we'll be here all day making diagrams with straws. It doesn't matter.It doesn't matter because I don't know how it works. Nobody knows how it works. Time travel was an accident, thirty years from now the smartest men in the world know exactly one thing about it that you don't: they know to be scared to death of it.And the salt. No, the pepper. The pepper. Old Joe sets two straws about a foot apart, parallel, and pours pepper between them, thus:Ok, the span between the straws is a timeline of the next 30 years.The pepper is a sort of fog. He puts his hand on the folded papers.I'm gonna save her. A quick beat. Joe goes for his gun. But Old Joe is fast, he jams his foot into Joe's crotch, crushing the hidden gun into him. Joe cries out, Old Joe grabs his hair and plants his face into the table. When Joe's hands go to his face Old Joe grabs them and pulls. Foot in his crotch, pulling his arms tight over the table.The Rainmaker is alive right now. Living here, somewhere in this county. And I can find him with this. I need you to lay low, stay out of my way and not get caught. I know how to fix this, I won't stop till I finish it. I'm going to find him and kill him. Joe's face loosens, his eyes on their coffee cups.It's been thirty years for me, so it's hard to remember. When you stole Seth's bike you stripped out the security tracker. Right? Joe's fearful face says âno.' Old Joe draws his gat.Make it to the field, you can lose them in the field. Go east and hopShit. We're doing cake.Well you should join the party even if you don't have cake. You have a birthday coming up?I'm sorry. Old Joe leaves, walks across the grass. Having trouble breathing.But I will.I'd do anything for you.Anything. She smiles but does not believe him. Old Joe sees this. A moment, in thought.Anything.Don't. Don't wake up your daughter. Old Joe trains the gun on her. She goes silent.Sit down. At the kitchen table. Quivering, she does. He keeps the gun on her.Do you know me?I need to tell you why I'm doing this. I gotta say it out loud to someone so I know.I threw my gun away once. To get her love. And I was going to do it again, now. Because I know she'd want me to. I was going to do it. And I saw then, I saw her vanishing, like how life probably goes when you die. That's what she was asking me to give up this time.And if I picked up the gun. If I made this sacrifice. Life, my life. Absolution. Given back to me. My love. Given back, just like we were, and she wouldn't know what I did to get it back.Everything set right. Everything fixed. Through this sacrifice.The Rainmaker. A bare bulb hanging from the ceiling turns on. A six year old girl's room. But the only person in it is Kid Blue. He shoots Old Joe with a blue tazer. You take this truck, you take your money, and you go live your life. No one's coming after you. I fixed it.That's how. You got your life back, you better think right now about what that's worth to you.Stupid little shit! You let him live, he's gonna take away everything that's yours, everything that's mine! You seen what the boy's gonna become.Move!I'm sorry He pulls the trigger.

SARA.raw_line: C'mon baby. Time to get up.Listen up fucker. I have shot and buried three vagrants in the past year. If you want to know the Christ's honest truth I'm starting to get a taste for it. So I don't care what hobo sob story you've got, I get a dozen a week and it cuts no cash with me. It's me and my husband here, we're broke and angry at our lot in this world and heavily armed. So take some corn and move on, but if you show your face again I will cut you the fuck in half. Silence. Just the wind in the corn. A long beat. Then Sara turns, walks briskly back. Moments later Joe's face pokes through the corn stalks. He takes in the farm. The barn behind it. The fallow field.Hey. Who's there. Sara levels the shotgun at the darkness, and steps back. Quiet but definite - crunch crunch. And now, definitely a shape. A man. coming towards her.Stop right there. Stop!You stop right there, you stop! She fires her gun in the air. The man pauses, but then continues towards her. She trips on a root, FALLS.Jee sus. Hey, hey. I'm going to get you...great.Hey you forgot your greasy goddamn hobo sign oh for godssakes. Alright, what are you? Joe turns away from her quickly, but doubles over, crumpling to a heap on the grass. Sara checks his face.Hey. Look at - hey. The fuck- ehh. Joe PUKES. She steps away. Takes a moment. Breathes.Hey. Up here, at the light. Hey. Sara SLAPS HIM. Hard. His eyes snap open. He sees her face. She feels his head. Checks his eyes. Cherry red and veined, swollen under the lids.How long since you dropped?Dropped, or what the kids call it.One day. Wow. She leans back on her haunches, looks at him, deep in thought. Deciding what to do. Joe lies prone, shaking, sweating.You're withdrawing from a synthetic barbiturate. It's a quick punch but it's this bad a day in, without care you might not make it through the night. Sara looks at his shoes. Beneath the caked mud, fine leather. Her eyes linger on his gun. They turn cold.Just a vagrant babe.Oh yeah?Well aren't you a smart monkey.Yup.Yup.Go to sleep. Okay. Night baby boy. Kisses him.Ssssshhit.Water. Drink it, all night, more than you think you want. Moves a metal bucket next to the bed. Adjusts the blankets.Aim for the bucket. And don't chew your tongue off. In the morning we're gonna talk.Hey.Hey.Morning monkey.No.Toss it. Joe freezes. Then, half annoyedHow do you feel?Take it slow and by the end of the week you'll be at fifty. Good. She tosses him a key, he unlocks his handcuff.I took you in so you wouldn't die, and now you're not going to die.So take the morning to rest, then you need to get off my farm.I'm sorry?I am not cool with that.Well I'm sorry too, you just lost your take the morning to rest privileges, get off my farm.Get off my farm.This is a Remington 870, one blast could cut you the fuck in half.So now I saved your life that makes me weak?What is this?That's my house. Why is it marked?What is this. She shows him the number. She is not asking what the number is - she knows. Joe is suddenly not so relaxed.What is this.Who are you? She shoves the shotgun barrel in his face, a rush of furyYou're right I'm not a killer but I am fine with how a blast of rock salt to your face won't kill you. Who are you and what are you here for? Who are you? Joe breathes hard, bleeding in the dirt with a shotgun in his nose. But he forces calm. A beat. Then he starts talking.A Looper.I've heard stories. So he's coming here to murder me and my son because he thinks we might be this Rainmaker. And once he kills the Rainmaker, what happens?Who is he? The guy you let run? Just some random guy from the future?This is my son Cid's birthday. And this is the hospital he was born in. Joe's face, taking this in.Would he do this?If he comes here, can you stop him? She turns the paper over in her hands.Given this, if I erred on the side of caution and believed all of this, I'm asking. If I trusted you. Will you stop him before he gets to my son?No you cannot burn down my corn fields.Farm equipment.No farm equipment that shoots. No.You use what you need, set up anywhere. But one thing, I don't want you talking to Cid. I watch my son, you watch the corn. That's the deal.Hold still. Easy for things to get infected on a farm, start falling off.There's a dinner bell down by the barn, ring that if someone's coming, I'll hear it.Dunno what we've got but I'll look. She spots Cid at the screen door, watching them.Cid. She goes to take him inside.How's the maths coming?Help him what?Baby. Listen. I need you to stay away from that man. Okay? Let him-Let him do his thing, but you stay with me.Well we're gonna see what he is. But you stick with me. Yeah?Uh huh. She keeps chopping.When?What?Uh huh.He said that?So I dropped Cid with my mom, here. And my sister. And they saw how I was living and they took him. My sister raised him here, she loved him. He called her mom.I told you one thing, I told you to stay away from my son.Stay out of it. Stay the fuck away from my son.Where does 56 go? Good. 21.I don't know, awhile. That's a good question. Where's it go. Good, there. 32.Joe?He isn't our business.Baby. Let's do this now. You have 32 there, I know you know this one.Cid. 32. She goes to the window, looks out, nervous. But it's just a loose LAUNDRY LINE down in the yard, whipping in the wind against its metal pole. In the distance, Joe paces the yard. Relieved, Sara returns to Cid. He sets the tile, petulant.No. Eight times three is what?Eight times three is what?I want you to count three eights.Are you telling me you want alone time?Okay. Why don't you put that where it belongs? Deliberately, Cid lifts the tile and sets it straight back down on the same spot.Alone time.Ok. I told you to stay away fromDo you think I'm stupid?I told you already Cid is building into a temper tantrum fast.You do what I tell youEvenin. How can I help you?No, that's fine.What's this about? Back in the house somewhere, a screen door bangs.My husband should be back from the city, any time now.Course. I'll get some, you can take the glass with you.Will you tell me what this is about?No, vagrants are always passing but nobody near the house. Footsteps, as they walk deeper in the house. Joe can't tell if they're coming through the living room or hall. He hesitates.He's young. No. Then at the last moment Joe slips out the hallway door, as they enter from the living room. Sara leads Jesse in, holding a photograph of Joe. She pours him some water. Jesse hands her a second photograph.No. She tries to hand the photos back but Jesse doesn't take them. He notices the toys on the table.Yeah. Just one.Eight. Jesse pokes his head into the hallway, just missing Joe slipping through the hall and into the living room. He lifts his glass, drinks.I'll show you round the grounds, then the house, then you can be on your way. Sara holds the screen door open for him.This man dangerous?Drafts, in the house. Jesse is already moving fast to the kitchen. The instant Jesse exits, Cid appears again in the hallway. Opens a small door under the stairway and beckons Joe.It used to, it's busted. Joe hesitates, then silently dashes over and in.Farm house. Jesse walks to the thin wooden door. Opens it. Closes it. CREAK. He looks at Sara.Laundry room. Door must've blown open.It's a laundry room. Jesse motions - her first.If someone was hiding in the house, that's what I'd do. But nobody is in the house. Open it up.Now if you promise not to wag your gun at my shoe rack I'll show you upstairs then show you the fuck out. She storms up the stairs. A little cowed, Jesse holsters his gun and follows her. The water from the bucket flows in a small stream across the room, and into a drain hole under the hamper.Don't wake Cid. She pulls him to the bed, lifting his shirt off. The rain starts to fall against the windows.In the city, young guys would hit on me by floating fucking quarters, I wouldn't tell âem I was TK but I'd keep their quarters down. One guy busted a blood vessel in his eye trying to get it up.But you protected Cid. And I know you're not lying that you're gonna kill this guy, your own self. Even though he's protecting your future.When I came back, after my sister died. Cid was sitting on the porch, I remember seeing him for the first time, in two years.Saw him on the porch. I drove up crying and I had been at a party in the city when I got the call, I was wearing this ridiculous party dress. All my ridiculous shit. I don't know if he remembered me, but he looked at me. I abandoned him. I abandoned my baby.Joe. Joe. He wakes. She is calling him from downstairs.Cid! Cid!What are you doing with those guns? What are you going to do? She lunges for him, wild. Wrenches his arm and he spins, throwing her to the ground.No! No he was climbing a bookshelf, it fell back on him. He has no control, he gets scared, it explodes.Joe someday he'll learn to control it.If he did good with it! If he grew up good!You stay away from him! Cid! Cid! She runs into the corn.Cid! Make a noise baby, call to me! Cid! WITH JOE through the corn, following traces of blood on the stalks.You stay away from Joe, you come to me! Cid! Tries cocking the GAT but it's broken. Tosses it, wields the Blunderbuss.Where are you going? Joe takes the Frog Buzzer from his pocket, presses it. Sara's buzzes in her pocket.Ok baby, we're going.Here we go. Give it a wave goodbye.Duck down babyJust stay down Half the distance closed, but he's still far off. A shot cracks the front grill, another cracks the windshield.Are you ok?You're ok. C'mon baby we have to run now.We're going into the fields. I want you to run, I'll be right behind you, don't look back. Okay? Old Joe lowers his gun and runs towards them.Go! They both sprint off the road.No Cid no! The topsoil of the earth around them RISES in a fine dust.No! With a sudden jolt the field ripples out from Cid, like a stone thrown in a pond. Sara lifts into the air.You did good, baby. You did so good. I love you. Behind them, Old Joe struggles to his feet. Sara kisses Cid.Into the fields. Run now baby. Go.You go! She pushes him away and Cid runs. Then she turns. Standing her ground. Directly between Old Joe and Cid. Old Joe TRIPS in the mud, fumbles his gun. Sees Cid approaching the safety of the CORN STALKS. Blocked by Sara.He had to go away, baby.
